It suffices to specify an action on morphisms. Let f\colon A\to B be an arbitrary morphism. Since monomorphisms are stable under pullback, the pullback functor f^{*}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}\to {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} restricts to a functor f^{*}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(B)\to \mathsf {Sub}(A). Then pseudofunctoriality follows from the following facts:
Let f\colon A \to B, g\colon B \to C, and m\colon C' \rightarrowtail C be given. By the pasting lemma of pullbacks, the pullback f^{*}g^{*}(m) is also a pullback along gf. Thus, the universal property of pullbacks guarantees that (gf)^{*}(m) \cong f^{*}g^{*}(m) in \mathsf {Sub}(A).
The pullback against the identity is always an isomorphism. Thus, for any m\colon A' \rightarrowtail A, \mathsf {id}_{A}^{*}(m) \cong m in \mathsf {Sub}(A).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If \mathcal {C} has pullbacks then the assignment A \mapsto \mathsf {Sub}(A) can be extended to a pseudofunctor \mathsf {Sub}\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op} \to \mathsf {CAT}.
